title: How to Use Sugru

steps.headline: Avoid using Sugru on oily plastics and powder-coated metals.
steps.description: Sugru works best when applied to ceramics, glass, metal, wood, rubber, and dry plastics. However, it will struggle to bond with polypropylene, polyethylene, Teflon, or other plastics that have an oily finish to them. If possible, make the surface as dry and powder-free as possible before applying the Sugru to achieve the strongest adhesion.

steps.headline: Use Sugru in temperatures around 70 °F (21 °C) for best results.
steps.description: This is room temperature in most climate-controlled spaces and will allow the Sugru to cure most efficiently (in about 24 hours). Note that for every 20 °F (−7 °C) reduction in temperature, the Sugru will take twice as long to cure. For example, if you use Sugru in a room that’s around 50 °F (10 °C), it will take 48 hours to cure.

steps.headline: Store your unopened Sugru in the freezer to maximize its shelf life.
steps.description: Unfortunately, once you open a pack of Sugru, any of the adhesive that has come into contact with the air will have to be used right away before it cures. Unopened Sugru placed in the freezer, on the other hand, can last up to 3 times longer than the use-by date on the packaging.

steps.headline: Refrain from painting over your Sugru.
steps.description: Paint tends to flake over and crack when applied to Sugru, so you won’t be able to paint over your Sugru to make it blend in with its surroundings. Instead, mix and match different colored Sugru in order to achieve your desired shade before applying it. For example, if you want to make your Sugru purple, simply mix equal portions of red and blue Sugru before applying it.

steps.headline: Use Sugru with an iron-on patch to repair holes in your clothes.
steps.description: First, lay your article of clothing on a heat-resistant surface and iron the patch over the hole. Then, roll the Sugru into thin pieces and lay them along the edges of the patch. Finally, wet your fingers and use them to smooth out the Sugru so that it “blends” into the surrounding fabric. Adding Sugru to the corners of an iron-on patch will help the patch stay in place for a longer period of time. For best results, use a color of Sugru that either matches or complements the color of the clothing article. For example, red Sugru would work well with either red or orange clothing, but not with bright green clothes.Warning: Using an iron can be very dangerous, as it generates a lot of heat. Do not use an iron on an unstable surface, such as a bed, and keep children away from it while it’s in use.

steps.headline: Paste Sugru on the front of your shoes to repair damaged toe guards.
steps.description: Place a glob of Sugru on the tip of the damaged shoe. Then, use your fingers to simply spread the Sugru around until it covers the entire damaged portion of the shoe. This is especially useful if you have shoes that are meant to be waterproof, such as hiking boots, but which have cracks in them that allow water to seep through.

steps.headline: Fix frayed cables and torn hoses by wrapping Sugru around them.
steps.description: Place a small amount of Sugru over the part of the cable or hose that is torn. Then, use your fingers to spread the Sugru around the cable or hose until the entire damaged area is covered. If you’re repairing a water hose this way, allow 24 hours for the Sugru to cure. Then, test your repair by running water through the hose to see if it still leaks.

steps.headline: Repair plastic toys by using Sugru to put the pieces back together.
steps.description: All you have to do is place the Sugru on the sides of the broken pieces, then push those pieces back together. Once you’ve done this, give the Sugru 24 hours to cure before handing it back to your child. This will make the Sugru as set as possible, making it less likely to be broken again. You can also use Sugru to repair broken pieces of ceramic this way.

steps.headline: Put Sugru in gaps in your wooden floors to fill them in.
steps.description: Roll your Sugru into a long thin piece equal in size to the gap in your floor. Then, push the Sugru into the gap and smooth it out so that it’s even with the rest of the floor. For best results, use a colored Sugru that matches the color of your floor. This is especially important since you can’t actually paint over Sugru.

steps.headline: Wrap Sugru around the grips of pots and pans to insulate them.
steps.description: Sugru is heat-resistant up to 350 °F (177 °C), making it a terrific grip for pots and pans that are otherwise difficult to touch when hot. Wrap a thin layer of Sugru around the handle of a stainless steel pot or pan, then smooth it out to your desired level of smoothness. You can also do this to repair old broken zippers that need a new grip!

steps.headline: Embed a hook in a glob of Sugru and place it on the wall as a coat hook.
steps.description: Roll a piece of Sugru into a thick disc shape about 1 inch (2.5 cm) across and ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick. Press this disc onto the wall and push a wall hook into the disc to mount it to the wall. This allows you to put a hook on your wall without having to actually drill into it.Tip: You can also place a magnet on the Sugru disc instead of a hook in order to create a magnetic wall mount for your keys or any other tiny metal objects!

steps.headline: Put Sugru on the corners of gadgets to keep them from being damaged.
steps.description: Place a small dollop of Sugru on the vulnerable corners of your smartphone, tablet, or any other square-shaped piece of technology. Leave the Sugru to harden for 24 hours, or at least overnight, in order to get the best results. You can also place a thin layer of Sugru on other exposed parts of expensive gadgets. For example, make a digital camera child-safe by putting Sugru on the corners and around the edge of the lens hood.

steps.headline: Place globs of Sugru on the side of your desk to make a cable organizer.
steps.description: Roll a piece of Sugru into a thick disc shape about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick and push it onto the side edge of a table or desk. Push a toothpick into the middle of the disc until it almost hits the back of the Sugru. Remove the toothpick and push the 2 top pieces of the Sugru toward each other without actually having them touch. Finally, leave your new cable clip alone for 24 hours to set. Repeat this process to create a series of cable clips along the side of your desk or table.

steps.headline: Turn an old book into a tablet case by placing Sugru on the corners.
steps.description: First, take a hardcover book and carefully remove all the pages from the inside, leaving the spine and cover intact. Lay your device on 1 side of the inside of the book and mark the locations of the tablet corners. Remove the device and place globs of Sugru on each of these spots. Slightly bend each of these Sugru globs to form holders for your tablet. For best results, avoid using this DIY tablet case to actually hold a tablet for at least 24 hours. This will give the Sugru enough time to fully set and minimize the risk of the tablet popping out.

steps.headline: Add Sugru to the tops of coat hangers to make stoppers.
steps.description: Roll a small glob of Sugru into a short, thick piece, then place this piece about 2/3 of the way down the top of a coat hanger. Repeat this process to put a second stopper on the other side of the hanger. Coat hanger stoppers are perfect for storing dresses, tank tops, and other articles of clothing that don’t easily stay on ordinary hangers.
